intro: Styphelia ciliata, commonly known as the silky snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its low-growing, evergreen habit. The plant produces small, bell-shaped white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are densely packed, narrow, and covered in fine, silky hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. Styphelia ciliata thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in open, rocky habitats.
